A reminder to all members that the mailbox area is NOT to be used as a bus stop pick up parking area. The Ʊnes for failure to utilize the Bus Pick Up Location of the front parking lot are as follows:

With the nice weather starting, please keep in mind that driving around the Conashaugh Lakes Community with children in the back of your pick up trucks is not allowed. Conashaugh Lakes follows the Pennsylvania Code regarding vehicles. Under Chapter 37 -Miscellaneous Provisions, 3719 -Passengers in open trucks,  it is illegal to operate a truck at any speed if a child less than 18 years of age is occupying the bed of the truck or trailer.
OƯ road vehicles, ATV ' s and quads are not allowed on Conashaugh roads as per Rules and Regulations, Section 15.3 which states as follows:
Section 15.3 OFF ROAD VEHICLES (ATV ' s, Dirt Bikes, Recreational Vehicles, Snowmobiles, etc.)
All ATV ' s, dirt bikes, go -carts, snowmobiles, or any recreational vehicle designed to go oƯ the road are NOT PERMITTED upon any CLCA Road; Paved or Unpaved, Improved or Unimproved.

(a)Snow or weather -related Emergencies: ATV ' s that are equipped with a mounted snowplow, engaged in removing snow from driveways only, including their own or close neighbors (when operated by an adult), and not for hire, shall be authorized for use within CLCA. ATV ' s under no circumstances shall be used for trash runs or to pick up the daily mail.

(b)CLCA State of Emergency: In the event of a CLCA State of Emergency where a severe thunderstorm, ice storm, tornado or other natural disaster causes severe disruption to roadways that may prevent Emergency Services from proceeding to property within CLCA, ATV ' S may be used to assist during the State of Emergency.

In that case CLCA will issue an emergency pass to any operator of an ATV that is willing to assist in the emergency eƯort to restore normal operations within CLCA. Emergency Passes will be issued by the oƯice. The Emergency passes will be in eƯect only during the declared emergency. Operators will be required to operate under the leadership of an emergency director, whether it be local as designated by the Board of Directors or external.

(c)The operation of recreational vehicles in CLCA will be permitted only on the owners ' property and operated only between 10:00 A.M. and 8:00 P.M. during Eastern Standard Time and 10:00 A.M. -9:00 P .M. during Eastern Daylight Savings Time. Fines will be imposed.
MONTHLY SECURITY REPORT     Month Ending April 2025
Here is a list of suggestions of what we can do to keep our family, home and property safe.
Use solid core or metal doors for all entry points.
Install deadbolt locks on exterior doors.
Reinforce sliding glass doors with a security bar or pin.
Ensure all windows have secure locks and consider window bars or security ܪ lm.
Invest in a home security system with alarms, cameras, and motion detectors.
Display security system signage to deter potential intruders.
Install motion -activated lights around entry points and dark areas of your property.
Keep outdoor lights on during the night to increase visibility.
Use timers to turn on lights, radios, or TVs when you ' re not home.
Have a trusted neighbor collect your mail and packages while you ' re away.
Keep bushes and trees trimmed to eliminate hiding spots for intruders.
Use gravel or pebbles as ground cover near windows and doors to make noise when walked on.
Keep garage doors closed and locked.
Install a security camera or motion sensor light in the garage.
Consider smart locks and doorbell cameras to monitor entry points.
Use smart home systems that allow you to control lights and alarms remotely.
Avoid posting about your travel plans or being away from home on social media.
Wait until you ' re back home to share vacation photos.
9. Install a Peephole or Video Doorbell
Use a peephole or video doorbell to see who is at your door before opening it.
Store valuables, including electronics, jewelry, and important documents, in a safe or in hidden locations.
Avoid leaving expensive items in plain view, especially near windows.
Look out for each other ' s homes and report any suspicious activity
Consider installing window locks or security screens.
Use shatter -resistant glass or window ܪ lm to make it harder to break in.
By implementing these safety tips, you can signi ܪ cantly reduce the risk of a break -in and help protect your home and belongings.
IN CASE OF EMERGENCY YOUR FIRST CALL SHOULD ALWAYS BE TO 911

Start by preheaƟng your oven to 350°F (175°C). This ensures the treats bake evenly and become that perfect golden brown color.

Next you will need to combine the oat Ňour, grated apple, and blueberries inside one bowl. SƟr everything together, make sure the blueberries break down slightly to release their juices. Add the melted coconut oil and water, mixing unƟl the dough comes together.

MONTHLY SECURITY REPORT

Know your visitors When being buzzed from the front gate for entry, it is a good idea to ask who it is that ' s coming in to the community. We had an incident this past month wherein a homeowner thought she was leƫng her son and girlfriend in.  She did not ask who it was, but just buzzed them in. It turns out it was not her relaƟve, but someone else.  It is essenƟal that you know who you are leƫng in to our community.

Tele pad use -When entering the code for the tele pad, please follow these instrucƟons:

ONLY ENTER THE 4 NUMBERS NOT 4 NUMBERS CALL NOT 4 NUMBERS #

Example:  If your code is 1234, only enter 1234 Entering the code too many times incorrectly causes the tele pad to jam.

If you are at the gate and have entered the code correctly and it ' s still not working, it could be that the vehicle in front of you entered it wrong and it is now jammed.  You must clear it by pressing * and then enter the code again.

REMEMBER : ALL VISITORS ARE LET IN BY MEMBERS. SECURITY WILL NOT ALLOW ENTRY WITHOUT SPEAKING WITH THE HOMEOWNER AND GETTING PERMISSION AND PROPER VERIFICATION. IF YOU LIVE HERE AND FORGOT YOUR KEYCARD, MAKE SURE YOU HAVE PROPER IDENTIFICATION WITH YOU AS SECU-

RITY WILL NOT LET YOU IN WITHOUT IT.

When at the member gate and allowing a visitor to follow you in using your gate card, swipe your card to allow yourself in, then put your card on top of the box and allow your visitor to swipe themselves in. Get your card when they get inside the gates. Do not have your visitor tailgate you in. Tailgating becomes trespassing and citations will follow. All members must swipe in, including motorcycles.

Speeding and careless driving Watch out for your neighbor.  We almost had a head -on collision this past month because someone was speeding, not paying aƩenƟon to where they were going, came around a turn on the wrong side of the road, an almost hit an oncoming vehicle. We cant stress enough how important it is to drive carefully within the community ' s speed limit.

Regular garbage in the recycling bins seems to be an ongoing issue.  This must stop as the recycling company could possibly Įne us.

School Bus Bullying we had a complaint recently of bullying on the school bus by a new resident.  Please make all parents aware of this.  Bullying is unacceptable behavior, and their child may be a vicƟm of it and not say anything.  It ' s an important discussion to have at home.

Vehicles stopping on Conashaugh Trail to pick up children this is not acceptable but has been happening daily. The traĸc gets backed up and could potenƟally cause an accident with children running in the street to a car. Pick up your children from the buses in the designated pick -up spot in the front parking lot.

Vandalism a members ' home got egged not long ago.  He was quite upset, as I ' m sure we all would be.  Talk with your young adults at home regarding vandalism.

Strawberry and Honey Dog Biscuits

1 cup rolled oats

Ingredients

½ cup whole wheat Ňour (or almond Ňour for a grain -free opƟon)

1 tablespoon honey

1 cup fresh strawberries, Įnely chopped or mashed

1 egg

InstrucƟons

2 tablespoons unsweetened applesauce (opƟonal)

Frozen Strawberry Yogurt Dog Treats Ingredients

Plain Greek Yogurt

Strawberries, how many depends on how many treats you want to make.

Other opƟons to keep the red theme are beet juice or cranberries.

Puree the strawberries.

InstrucƟons

For a layered look, pour and freeze one ingredient at a Ɵme, starƟng with yogurt, and then strawberries.

Time will vary depending on the size of your ice cube mold.

Freeze for 4 -6 hours, or unƟl completely frozen.

Tips

Adding a liƩle water when blending the strawberries helps create a smoother texture that is easier to pour into your mold.

Frozen strawberries work just as well as fresh. However, allowing them to defrost for a bit makes them easier to blend.

Do not Įll the mold to the top, leave room for expansion when freezing.

Preheat your oven to 350°F (175°C) and line a baking sheet with parchment paper.

Add the honey, egg, and applesauce to the mashed strawberries and mix well.

In a mixing bowl, mash the strawberries using a fork or masher.

Gradually add the rolled oats and Ňour, sƟrring unƟl a dough forms. Adjust consistency with addiƟonal Ňour or water if needed.

Place the biscuits on the baking sheet and bake for 15 -20 minutes unƟl golden brown and Įrm. Let the biscuits cool completely before serving.

Lightly Ňour a surface and roll out the dough to ¼ inch thickness. Use cookie cuƩers or shape the biscuits by hand.

Store treats in the freezer for up to 6 months (if they last that long).

February is American Heart Month, a Ɵme dedicated to raising awareness about heart disease and promoƟng cardiovascular health. Here are some Ɵps and informaƟon to help you prioriƟze your heart health in February and beyond: Understanding Heart Health

-Blood Pressure: Aim for a reading below 120/80 mm Hg. Always follow your physician ' s recommendaƟons.

Know Your Numbers:

-Cholesterol Levels: Keep total cholesterol below 200 mg/dL, with LDL (bad cholesterol) lower than 100 mg/dL, and HDL (good cholesterol) above 50 mg/dL for women and 40 mg/dL for men.

Recognize the Symptoms:

-Blood Sugar: Keep your fasƟng blood sugar levels below 100 mg/dL to reduce diabetes risk and follow the advice of your physician.

-Be aware of common heart aƩack symptoms such as chest pain, shortness of breath, nausea, and discomfort in the arms, back, neck, or jaw. Symptoms diīer in men and women.

-

Eat a Heart -Healthy Diet:

Tips for a Heart

Healthy Lifestyle

-Fruits and Vegetables: Aim for at least 5 servings a day.

-Healthy Fats: Incorporate sources of omega -3 faƩy acids, such as salmon, walnuts, and Ňaxseeds, while limiƟng saturated and trans fats.

-Whole Grains: Choose whole -grain bread, pasta, and cereals.

-Limit Sodium: Reduce salt intake to help lower blood pressure.

-Aim for at least 150 minutes of moderate aerobic acƟvity or 75 minutes of vigorous acƟvity each week. AcƟviƟes can include brisk walking, cycling, swimming, or dancing.

Stay AcƟve:

Maintain a Healthy Weight:

Quit Smoking:

-Keep a healthy body weight through a balanced diet and regular exercise. Even a modest weight loss can improve heart health.

-If you smoke, seek help to quit. Smoking is a major risk factor for heart disease.

-If you drink alcohol, do so in moderaƟon. This generally means up to one drink a day for women and up to two drinks a day for men.

Limit Alcohol:

Manage Stress:

Regular Check -Ups:

-PracƟce stress -reducing techniques such as yoga, meditaƟon, or deep breathing exercises. Geƫng enough sleep is also crucial for stress management.

-Schedule regular visits with your healthcare provider to monitor your heart health and discuss any concerns. RouƟne screenings can help catch potenƟal issues early.

Wear Red:

Community Engagement and Awareness

-ParƟcipate in NaƟonal Wear Red Day (usually the Įrst Friday in February) to raise awareness about heart disease in women.

-Share informaƟon about heart health with family and friends.

Educate Others:

Support Research:

Volunteer:

-Consider donaƟng to organizaƟons that fund heart disease research and support awareness campaigns, such as the American Heart AssociaƟon.

-Look for local heart health iniƟaƟves or events such as walkathons, health fairs, or educaƟonal seminars where you can contribute your Ɵme.

By focusing on heart health during February and integraƟng these pracƟces into your daily life, you can make a posiƟve impact on your cardiovascular well -being. Remember, small changes can lead to signiĮcant improvements over Ɵme. Take charge of your heart health today!

Chocolate Banana Bread

1 cup all - purpose Ňour

1/4 cup buƩer, melted & slightly cooled

1/2 cup Dutch process cocoa

1/4 cup canola vegetable oil

1 teaspoon baking soda

3/4 cup  packed light brown sugar

1/2 teaspoon sea salt

1 large egg, at room temperature

3 large brown bananas (1 ½ cups mashed) 1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract

1 cup semisweet chocolate chips, divided

Ingredients

InstrucƟons

Heat your oven to 350°F. Grease a 9 -by -5 -inch loaf pan with nonsƟck cooking spray and set aside.

In a large bowl, mash the ripe bananas with a fork. Add the melted buƩer and oil and sƟr unƟl combined. SƟr in the brown sugar, egg, and vanilla extract. SƟr unƟl smooth.

In a medium bowl, whisk together the Ňour, cocoa powder, baking soda, and sea salt. Set it aside.

SƟr the dry ingredients into the wet ingredients, don't overmix. SƟr in ¾ cup of the chocolate chips.

Remove the pan from the oven and set on a wire cooling rack. Let the bread cool in the pan for 15 minutes. Run a knife around the edges of the bread and carefully remove it from the pan. Let the bread cool on the wire cooling rack unƟl slightly warm. Cut into slices and serve.

Pour baƩer into prepared pan. Sprinkle the remaining ¼ cup of chocolate chips over the top of the bread. Bake for 50 -65 minutes, or unƟl a toothpick inserted into the center of the bread comes out mostly clean, you might have some melted chocolate chips on the toothpick and that is Įne. You just don't want a lot of gooey baƩer. Check at 50 minutes, just to be safe. Oven Ɵmes vary.

The History of Lords Valley

In 1809, Levi Lord, along with his son, Simeon, and twelve associates from England, came to this region in hopes of purchasing a land tract from Dr. Phillip Myddleton.

Discovering some title problems, the entire group except for Lord decided to purchase elsewhere. In 1810, Lord procured a valid title, and the property became part of the Blooming Grove Township.

The Lord ' s of Liverpool made their first home in the cabin of Sam Helm, a noted woodsman who ' squatted ' on the land. Helm acknowledged Lord ' s claim to the property and offered it to him, and in the same gentlemanly spirit, Lord is said to have paid Helm for his improvements.

The Lord ' s began to make their living in the abundant timber. In response to traffic in the area, Simeon Lord built a hotel in 1850. (The Lord House is today a Pike County Historic Site as well as a State Historical site.) In the early part of the 20 th century, Sim Lord Jr., son of Simeon Lord and grandson of Levi Ford, managed the hotel and sold gasoline. The Lords Valley Post Office also operated out of the Lord House from 1853 until 1955 when the Hawley Post Office.

According to the county veterans' grave registration card filed in 1935 by the PA Department of Military Affairs, Levi Lord was an army veteran, having served in the Revolutionary War and ' local Indian war. ' assumed responsibilities.

(The Lord House is the old red brick house located on Rt. 739 across from 84 Lumber)

The Stage Coach ' The Hiawatha ' stopped at the Lords House while it was a Post Office.

Incident Category by Day of Week

Know your visitors When being buzzed from the front gate for entry, it is a good idea to ask who it is that ' s coming in to the community. We had an incident this past month wherein a homeowner thought she was leƫng her son and girlfriend in.  She did not ask who it was, but just buzzed them in. It turns out it was not her relaƟve, but someone else.  It is essenƟal that you know who you are leƫng in to our community.
Tele pad use -When entering the code for the tele pad, please follow these instrucƟons:
ONLY ENTER THE 4 NUMBERS NOT 4 NUMBERS CALL NOT 4 NUMBERS #
Example:  If your code is 1234, only enter 1234 Entering the code too many times incorrectly causes the tele pad to jam.

If you are at the gate and have entered the code correctly and it ' s still not working, it could be that the vehicle in front of you entered it wrong and it is now jammed.  You must clear it by pressing * and then enter the code again.

REMEMBER : ALL VISITORS ARE LET IN BY MEMBERS. SECURITY WILL NOT ALLOW ENTRY WITHOUT SPEAKING WITH THE HOMEOWNER AND GETTING PERMISSION AND PROPER VERIFICATION. IF YOU LIVE HERE AND FORGOT YOUR KEYCARD, MAKE SURE YOU HAVE PROPER IDENTIFICATION WITH YOU AS SECU-
RITY WILL NOT LET YOU IN WITHOUT IT.

When at the member gate and allowing a visitor to follow you in using your gate card, swipe your card to allow yourself in, then put your card on top of the box and allow your visitor to swipe themselves in. Get your card when they get inside the gates. Do not have your visitor tailgate you in. Tailgating becomes trespassing and citations will follow. All members must swipe in, including motorcycles.

Speeding and careless driving Watch out for your neighbor.  We almost had a head -on collision this past month because someone was speeding, not paying aƩenƟon to where they were going, came around a turn on the wrong side of the road, an almost hit an oncoming vehicle. We cant stress enough how important it is to drive carefully within the community ' s speed limit.
Regular garbage in the recycling bins seems to be an ongoing issue.  This must stop as the recycling company could possibly Įne us.

School Bus Bullying we had a complaint recently of bullying on the school bus by a new resident.  Please make all parents aware of this.  Bullying is unacceptable behavior, and their child may be a vicƟm of it and not say anything.  It ' s an important discussion to have at home.

Vehicles stopping on Conashaugh Trail to pick up children this is not acceptable but has been happening daily. The traĸc gets backed up and could potenƟally cause an accident with children running in the street to a car. Pick up your children from the buses in the designated pick -up spot in the front parking lot.
Vandalism a members ' home got egged not long ago.  He was quite upset, as I ' m sure we all would be.  Talk with your young adults at home regarding vandalism.

As we start 2025 be sure that all car registrations are updated with the CLCA Office. Stop in and see Liz, I know she would love to see you and give her copies of all updated car registrations. Every car with a gate card should have an updated registration on file.
Or email them to Liz at adminassistant@conashaughlakes.com

Just a gentle reminder that     parking in the mailbox area to pick children up from the school bus is not permitted.
It is unsafe and puts your child at risk of being hit by a car.
Please use the bus area for drop off and pick up, the two extra minutes you spend may save a life.

February is American Heart Month, a Ɵme dedicated to raising awareness about heart disease and promoƟng cardiovascular health. Here are some Ɵps and informaƟon to help you prioriƟze your heart health in February and beyond: Understanding Heart Health
-Blood Pressure: Aim for a reading below 120/80 mm Hg. Always follow your physician ' s recommendaƟons.
-Cholesterol Levels: Keep total cholesterol below 200 mg/dL, with LDL (bad cholesterol) lower than 100 mg/dL, and HDL (good cholesterol) above 50 mg/dL for women and 40 mg/dL for men.
-Blood Sugar: Keep your fasƟng blood sugar levels below 100 mg/dL to reduce diabetes risk and follow the advice of your physician.
-Be aware of common heart aƩack symptoms such as chest pain, shortness of breath, nausea, and discomfort in the arms, back, neck, or jaw. Symptoms diīer in men and women.
-Fruits and Vegetables: Aim for at least 5 servings a day.
-Healthy Fats: Incorporate sources of omega -3 faƩy acids, such as salmon, walnuts, and Ňaxseeds, while limiƟng saturated and trans fats.
-Whole Grains: Choose whole -grain bread, pasta, and cereals.
-Limit Sodium: Reduce salt intake to help lower blood pressure.
-Aim for at least 150 minutes of moderate aerobic acƟvity or 75 minutes of vigorous acƟvity each week. AcƟviƟes can include brisk walking, cycling, swimming, or dancing.
-Keep a healthy body weight through a balanced diet and regular exercise. Even a modest weight loss can improve heart health.
-If you smoke, seek help to quit. Smoking is a major risk factor for heart disease.
-If you drink alcohol, do so in moderaƟon. This generally means up to one drink a day for women and up to two drinks a day for men.
-PracƟce stress -reducing techniques such as yoga, meditaƟon, or deep breathing exercises. Geƫng enough sleep is also crucial for stress management.
-Schedule regular visits with your healthcare provider to monitor your heart health and discuss any concerns. RouƟne screenings can help catch potenƟal issues early.
-ParƟcipate in NaƟonal Wear Red Day (usually the Įrst Friday in February) to raise awareness about heart disease in women.
-Share informaƟon about heart health with family and friends.
-Consider donaƟng to organizaƟons that fund heart disease research and support awareness campaigns, such as the American Heart AssociaƟon.
-Look for local heart health iniƟaƟves or events such as walkathons, health fairs, or educaƟonal seminars where you can contribute your Ɵme.

By focusing on heart health during February and integraƟng these pracƟces into your daily life, you can make a posiƟve impact on your cardiovascular well -being. Remember, small changes can lead to signiĮcant improvements over Ɵme. Take charge of your heart health today!

❤ Let's give The Ronald McDonald House ❤ ❤ a Big Conashaugh Helping Hand ❤

Boxes will be hung, with the picture below of Pop Tabs by the Mailboxes, Office, Recreation Building and Compactors. Drop off all your Pop Tabs and I will bring them to the Ronald McDonald House packaged with love from The Members of Conashaugh Lakes

This baseball season at PNC Field, home of the Scranton/Wilkes-Barre  RailRiders, the Ronald McDonald House of Scranton is going BIG! They're on a mission to collect more Pop Tabs than ever before and set a world record -all while helping families stay close to their children's medical care.

Why Pop Tabs?

They are pure aluminum, easy to collect, and turn into funding for their House. Every tab helps provide housing, meals, and support to families in need. The more they collect, the closer they get to making history!

The Rules on Fireworks Safety

You know the damage Įreworks can do to humans: severe burns and mangled Įngers. The fact is the environment is also at risk from pyrotechnics. A Įrecracker Ňung by a 15 -year -old boy during a burn ban started a 2017 Įre in Oregon ' s Columbia River Gorge that burned for three months and charred 50,000 acres. Pockets of Įre were sƟll smoldering nine months aŌer the blaze began.

The lesson here is clear enough. You need to observe extreme care in celebraƟng the 4th with Įreworks. Know all the dangers before you light the Įrst fuse.

The safety Ɵps from Homeland Security come from its TransportaƟon Safety Laboratory (TSL).

❖ Never place a part of your body directly over a Įrework or hold a Įrework in your hand when lighƟng.

❖ Always use Įreworks outdoors and keep a bucket of water or a hose nearby in case of accidents.

❖ Light only one Įrework at a Ɵme.

❖ For ground -based devices such as fountains, the perimeter should be 35 feet out.

❖ Designate a safe perimeter to keep people safely away from Įreworks.

❖ For aerial devices, it should be 150 feet. Fireworks that don't go oī when you light them can sƟll explode.

❖ Let duds sit for Įve or 10 minutes before you pick them up to dowse them in water.

Include pet safety as well as human safety in your plans. Pets Įnd Įreworks highly stressful. Bring your pets indoors, close curtains and blinds and turn on the radio to provide some distracƟon. Leave treats Įlled with food to comfort animals.

Keep the weather in mind when using Įreworks. Never use Įreworks if your locale has a burn ban. Never set oī Įreworks where falling embers could ignite buildings or vegetaƟon.

Homeland Security suggests using alternaƟves to Įreworks such as party poppers, bubbles, silly string, or glow sƟcks.

Sparklers may appear to be a safe alternaƟve to things that go boom, but they are not. The NSC says sparklers burn at 2,000 degrees enough to melt metal. For children under Įve, sparklers account for half of all Įreworks injuries. Keep them away from kids and use glow sƟcks, confeƫ poppers or colored streamers.

Final word on Įreworks comes from the NaƟonal Safety Council, which oīers this as the safest way to enjoy Įreworks: ' Grab a blanket and a patch of lawn. Kick back and let the experts handle the Įreworks show. '

Recognizing Dry Drowning: What You Need to Know

As summer approaches and water activities become more popular, it ' s essential for parents and caregivers to be aware of a condition known as dry drowning. While it is rare, understanding what it is and how to recognize its symptoms can be crucial for keeping children safe around water.

What is Dry Drowning?

Dry drowning occurs when a person has difficulty breathing after being submerged in water, but it does not always involve the lungs filling with water. Instead, it can happen when a person inhales water, causing a spasm in the airway that prevents breathing. This can occur immediately after a near -drowning incident or, in some cases, several hours later.

Signs and Symptoms to Watch For

It ' s essential to monitor for symptoms of dry drowning after a child has been in or around water. Here are some key signs to look out for:

Difficulty Breathing: If the child is struggling to breathe, has wheezing, or shows signs of labored breathing, it ' s crucial to act quickly.

Coughing: A persistent cough can indicate that water has entered the airway.

Chest Pain: Complaints of pain or discomfort in the chest may signal a serious issue.

Irritability or Changes in Behavior: If a child is unusually cranky or difficult to wake, it could indicate a problem.

Extreme Fatigue or Drowsiness: Unusual tiredness or lethargy can be a symptom of dry drowning, especially if it occurs after swimming.

What to Do If You Suspect Dry Drowning

If you notice any of the symptoms listed above after a child has been in water, take the following steps:

-Monitor Breathing: Keep an eye on the child ' s breathing patterns and be ready to perform CPR if necessary.

-Seek Immediate Medical Attention: If the symptoms are severe or worsening, call emergency services or take the child to the nearest hospital.

-Stay Calm: Your calm demeanor can help reassure the child during a frightening situation.

Prevention is Key

While dry drowning is rare, it ' s important to take precautions to prevent drowning incidents in the first place:

-Ensure everyone knows how to swim and is comfortable in the water.

-Always supervise children closely when they are in or near water.

-Enroll children in swimming lessons to boost their confidence and skills.

Conclusion

Understanding dry drowning and recognizing its symptoms can help ensure the safety of children around water. By staying vigilant and taking preventive measures, you can enjoy a safe and fun summer filled with water activities!

Stay Safe During a Heat Wave! ☀️

Extreme heat can be dangerous-take steps now to protect yourself, your loved ones, and your pets.

✅ Heat Safety Tips:

Stay indoors in air conditioning as much as possible

Drink plenty of water-avoid alcohol and caffeine

Wear light, loose -fitting clothing

NEVER leave children or pets in a parked car

Check on elderly neighbors and those with health conditions

Know the Signs of Heat Illness:

Heat Exhaustion: Heavy sweating, weakness, dizziness, nausea, headache

Heat Stroke (Emergency!): High body temp (103°F+), confusion, rapid pulse, no sweating

➡️ If you suspect heat stroke, call 911 immediately.

Pet Safety:

Keep pets indoors during peak heat hours

Provide fresh water and shade

Hot pavement can burn paws-walk pets early morning or evening

The BeneĮts of Volunteering: Why You Should Get Involved in Your Community

Volunteering is one of the most rewarding acƟviƟes you can engage in, both for yourself and for your community. Whether you ' re lending a helping hand at the annual picnic, parƟcipaƟng in a community cleanup, or helping the kids do an art project, the beneĮts of volunteering are abundant. Here are some compelling reasons to consider geƫng involved:

1. Make a PosiƟve Impact

One of the most signiĮcant beneĮts of volunteering is the opportunity to make a diīerence in the lives of others. Your Ɵme and eīort can help improve your community, support those in need, and create a more inclusive environment. Knowing that your acƟons contribute to a greater cause can be incredibly fulĮlling.

2. Build ConnecƟons

Volunteering allows you to meet new people who share your interests and values. You ' ll have the chance to connect with fellow volunteers, community members, and even those you ' re helping. These relaƟonships can lead to lasƟng friendships, a stronger support network, and a greater sense of belonging in your community.

3. Learn New Skills

When you volunteer, you oŌen have the opportunity to learn and develop new skills. Whether it ' s project management, communicaƟon, or even speciĮc skills like gardening or teaching, volunteering can enhance your resume and prepare you for future opportuniƟes. Plus, it ' s a great way to explore new interests!

4. Boost Your Mental Health

Numerous studies have shown that volunteering can improve mental health. Helping others can reduce stress, combat depression, and increase feelings of happiness and saƟsfacƟon. The sense of purpose that comes from giving back can lead to greater overall well -being.

5. Gain a New PerspecƟve

Volunteering exposes you to diīerent experiences and viewpoints that you might not encounter in your daily life. This can lead to greater empathy and understanding, helping you appreciate the diversity within your community. It can also inspire you to take acƟon in other areas of your life.

6. Enhance Your Community

When you volunteer, you contribute to the beƩerment of your community. Your eīorts can lead to cleaner parks, more accessible resources for those in need, and programs that support educaƟon, health, and well -being. Together, volunteers can create a stronger, more vibrant community for everyone. Create LasƟng Memories

The experiences you gain through volunteering can be some of the most memorable moments of your life. From organizing events to parƟcipaƟng in community acƟviƟes, you ' ll create stories and memories that you can cherish for years to come. Get Involved Today!

With so many beneĮts to gain, it ' s Ɵme to take the plunge and get involved in your community. Look for commiƩees or events that resonate with you, and don ' t hesitate to reach out. Whether you have a few hours or a long -term commitment to oīer, your contribuƟon can make a signiĮcant diīerence.

Volunteering is not just about helping others; it ' s about enriching your own life in the process. So why wait? Join the movement of community volunteers and experience the joy and fulĮllment that comes from giving back!

Ingredients:

1/2 cup blueberries

Place Cat Treats in Ice Cube Tray: You will put the cat treats in the boƩom of the tray.

Pour into Ice Cube Tray: Once you have your banana -Catmilk puree ready, pour it into the ice cube tray over the cat treats.

Serve: When the treats are fully frozen, remove them from the tray and oīer one to your cat. Keep the remaining treats stored in an airƟght container in the freezer.

Let ' s have some fun making glue suncatchers

Ingredients You ' ll Need

1 plasƟc lid (such as from a yogurt or sour cream container)

A few drops of food coloring (various colors)

Clear school glue (enough to cover the boƩom of your lid)

1 toothpick (for swirling the colors)

1 piece of ribbon, string, or Įshing line (for hanging)

1 hole punch (to make a hole for hanging)

Step -by -Step Instructions

Begin by choosing a plasƟc lid that will act as the base for your suncatcher. Clean it thoroughly and dry it completely.

AŌerward, carefully add several drops of food coloring into the glue. You can opt for one color or mulƟple to create a rainbow -like eīect.

Next, pour clear school glue into the lid unƟl it covers the enƟre boƩom. Gently Ɵlt the lid if needed to spread the glue evenly.

Then, take your toothpick and gently swirl the food coloring through the glue. Be careful not to overmix, so the colors remain disƟnct and don ' t muddy.

Once fully dry and Įrm, remove the suncatcher from the lid. It should peel away easily. If it sƟcks, gently Ňex the lid to loosen it.

Now, set the lid aside in a safe, level place to dry. Depending on the glue ' s thickness and humidity levels, drying could take anywhere from 8 to 24 hours.

Use a hole punch to make a hole near the top of your suncatcher.

Finally, thread your ribbon or string through the hole, Ɵe a knot, and hang your suncatcher in a sunny window to admire the vibrant colors shining through!

HOME SECURITY

Here is a list of suggestions of what we can do to keep our family, home and property safe.

1. Secure Doors and Windows

Use solid core or metal doors for all entry points.

Install deadbolt locks on exterior doors.

Reinforce sliding glass doors with a security bar or pin.

Ensure all windows have secure locks and consider window bars or security ܪ lm.

2. Install a Security System

Invest in a home security system with alarms, cameras, and motion detectors.

Display security system signage to deter potential intruders.

3. Use Outdoor Lighting

Install motion -activated lights around entry points and dark areas of your property.

Keep outdoor lights on during the night to increase visibility.

4. Create the Illusion of Occupancy

Use timers to turn on lights, radios, or TVs when you ' re not home.

Have a trusted neighbor collect your mail and packages while you ' re away.

5. Maintain Your Yard

Keep bushes and trees trimmed to eliminate hiding spots for intruders.

Use gravel or pebbles as ground cover near windows and doors to make noise when walked on.

6. Secure Your Garage

Keep garage doors closed and locked.

Install a security camera or motion sensor light in the garage.

7. Use Smart Technology

Consider smart locks and doorbell cameras to monitor entry points.

Use smart home systems that allow you to control lights and alarms remotely.

8. Be Cautious with Social Media

Avoid posting about your travel plans or being away from home on social media.

Wait until you ' re back home to share vacation photos.

9. Install a Peephole or Video Doorbell

Use a peephole or video doorbell to see who is at your door before opening it.

10. Keep Valuables Out of Sight

Store valuables, including electronics, jewelry, and important documents, in a safe or in hidden locations.

Avoid leaving expensive items in plain view, especially near windows.

11. Know Your Neighbors

Look out for each other ' s homes and report any suspicious activity

12. Reinforce Windows

Consider installing window locks or security screens.

Use shatter -resistant glass or window ܪ lm to make it harder to break in.

By implementing these safety tips, you can signi ܪ cantly reduce the risk of a break -in and help protect your home and belongings.

IN CASE OF EMERGENCY YOUR FIRST CALL SHOULD ALWAYS BE TO 911

Stay Safe During a Heat Wave! ☀️
Extreme heat can be dangerous-take steps now to protect yourself, your loved ones, and your pets.
Stay indoors in air conditioning as much as possible
Drink plenty of water-avoid alcohol and caffeine
NEVER leave children or pets in a parked car
Check on elderly neighbors and those with health conditions
Know the Signs of Heat Illness:
Heat Exhaustion: Heavy sweating, weakness, dizziness, nausea, headache
Heat Stroke (Emergency!): High body temp (103°F+), confusion, rapid pulse, no sweating
➡️ If you suspect heat stroke, call 911 immediately.
Keep pets indoors during peak heat hours
Hot pavement can burn paws-walk pets early morning or evening

The BeneĮts of Volunteering: Why You Should Get Involved in Your Community

Volunteering is one of the most rewarding acƟviƟes you can engage in, both for yourself and for your community. Whether you ' re lending a helping hand at the annual picnic, parƟcipaƟng in a community cleanup, or helping the kids do an art project, the beneĮts of volunteering are abundant. Here are some compelling reasons to consider geƫng involved:

One of the most signiĮcant beneĮts of volunteering is the opportunity to make a diīerence in the lives of others. Your Ɵme and eīort can help improve your community, support those in need, and create a more inclusive environment. Knowing that your acƟons contribute to a greater cause can be incredibly fulĮlling.

Volunteering allows you to meet new people who share your interests and values. You ' ll have the chance to connect with fellow volunteers, community members, and even those you ' re helping. These relaƟonships can lead to lasƟng friendships, a stronger support network, and a greater sense of belonging in your community.

When you volunteer, you oŌen have the opportunity to learn and develop new skills. Whether it ' s project management, communicaƟon, or even speciĮc skills like gardening or teaching, volunteering can enhance your resume and prepare you for future opportuniƟes. Plus, it ' s a great way to explore new interests!

Numerous studies have shown that volunteering can improve mental health. Helping others can reduce stress, combat depression, and increase feelings of happiness and saƟsfacƟon. The sense of purpose that comes from giving back can lead to greater overall well -being.

Volunteering exposes you to diīerent experiences and viewpoints that you might not encounter in your daily life. This can lead to greater empathy and understanding, helping you appreciate the diversity within your community. It can also inspire you to take acƟon in other areas of your life.

When you volunteer, you contribute to the beƩerment of your community. Your eīorts can lead to cleaner parks, more accessible resources for those in need, and programs that support educaƟon, health, and well -being. Together, volunteers can create a stronger, more vibrant community for everyone. Create LasƟng Memories

The experiences you gain through volunteering can be some of the most memorable moments of your life. From organizing events to parƟcipaƟng in community acƟviƟes, you ' ll create stories and memories that you can cherish for years to come. Get Involved Today!

With so many beneĮts to gain, it ' s Ɵme to take the plunge and get involved in your community. Look for commiƩees or events that resonate with you, and don ' t hesitate to reach out. Whether you have a few hours or a long -term commitment to oīer, your contribuƟon can make a signiĮcant diīerence.

Volunteering is not just about helping others; it ' s about enriching your own life in the process. So why wait? Join the movement of community volunteers and experience the joy and fulĮllment that comes from giving back!
Ever seen a dog try to eat a blueberry? You might get a free comedy show. These berry frozen yogurt cubes blend fun and antioxidants. Win -win.
Blend berries and yogurt until beautifully purple and creamy.
Pour the mixture into ice molds-in whatever ridiculous shapes you want.
Confession: These are actually pretty tasty for humans, too (but don ' t tell your dog).
Ripe bananas Cat treats Catmilk such as Whiskas Catmilk
Peel and Slice the Bananas: Start by peeling the ripe bananas and cuƫng them into small, bite -sized pieces. This makes it easier to blend later.
Place Cat Treats in Ice Cube Tray: You will put the cat treats in the boƩom of the tray.

Blend the Bananas: Place the banana slices into a blender or food processor and add the Catmilk. Blend unƟl you achieve a smooth and creamy consistency. You will make at a raƟo of one banana to one Catmilk container.
Pour into Ice Cube Tray: Once you have your banana -Catmilk puree ready, pour it into the ice cube tray over the cat treats.
Serve: When the treats are fully frozen, remove them from the tray and oīer one to your cat. Keep the remaining treats stored in an airƟght container in the freezer.
Freeze: Place the Įlled mold in your freezer and let it freeze for a few hours or unƟl the treats are solid.
Let ' s have some fun making glue suncatchers
1 plasƟc lid (such as from a yogurt or sour cream container)
A few drops of food coloring (various colors)
Clear school glue (enough to cover the boƩom of your lid)
1 piece of ribbon, string, or Įshing line (for hanging)
1 hole punch (to make a hole for hanging)
Begin by choosing a plasƟc lid that will act as the base for your suncatcher. Clean it thoroughly and dry it completely.
AŌerward, carefully add several drops of food coloring into the glue. You can opt for one color or mulƟple to create a rainbow -like eīect.
Next, pour clear school glue into the lid unƟl it covers the enƟre boƩom. Gently Ɵlt the lid if needed to spread the glue evenly.
Then, take your toothpick and gently swirl the food coloring through the glue. Be careful not to overmix, so the colors remain disƟnct and don ' t muddy.
Once fully dry and Įrm, remove the suncatcher from the lid. It should peel away easily. If it sƟcks, gently Ňex the lid to loosen it.
Now, set the lid aside in a safe, level place to dry. Depending on the glue ' s thickness and humidity levels, drying could take anywhere from 8 to 24 hours.
Use a hole punch to make a hole near the top of your suncatcher.
Finally, thread your ribbon or string through the hole, Ɵe a knot, and hang your suncatcher in a sunny window to admire the vibrant colors shining through!

Here is a list of suggestions of what we can do to keep our family, home and property safe.
Use solid core or metal doors for all entry points.
Install deadbolt locks on exterior doors.
Reinforce sliding glass doors with a security bar or pin.
Ensure all windows have secure locks and consider window bars or security ܪ lm.
Invest in a home security system with alarms, cameras, and motion detectors.
Display security system signage to deter potential intruders.
Install motion -activated lights around entry points and dark areas of your property.
Keep outdoor lights on during the night to increase visibility.
Use timers to turn on lights, radios, or TVs when you ' re not home.
Have a trusted neighbor collect your mail and packages while you ' re away.
Keep bushes and trees trimmed to eliminate hiding spots for intruders.
Use gravel or pebbles as ground cover near windows and doors to make noise when walked on.
Keep garage doors closed and locked.
Install a security camera or motion sensor light in the garage.
Consider smart locks and doorbell cameras to monitor entry points.
Use smart home systems that allow you to control lights and alarms remotely.
Avoid posting about your travel plans or being away from home on social media.
Wait until you ' re back home to share vacation photos.
9. Install a Peephole or Video Doorbell
Use a peephole or video doorbell to see who is at your door before opening it.
Store valuables, including electronics, jewelry, and important documents, in a safe or in hidden locations.
Avoid leaving expensive items in plain view, especially near windows.
Look out for each other ' s homes and report any suspicious activity
Consider installing window locks or security screens.
Use shatter -resistant glass or window ܪ lm to make it harder to break in.
By implementing these safety tips, you can signi ܪ cantly reduce the risk of a break -in and help protect your home and belongings.

The Conashaugh Lakes Annual Picnic! The Conashaugh Lakes Annual Picnic!

EVENT HIGHLIGHT

With close to 200 attendees, the annual picnic surpassed expectations. It was a beautiful day of full plates and full hearts as our community came together down by Seneca Lake. We met up with old friends and made new ones while we ate our fill of classic picnic foods. If only every Saturday could be like this!

First member checking in. Good thing he preordered tickets. He didn't like the idea of a wristband though.

/g1C0 FUN AND GAMES

Games aplenty: Cornhole, Connect Four, badminton, horseshoes, and some new games being invented on the spot

Bocce Ball court seeing some action

Some brought their own games and activities to play and share.

/g1A5 MUSIC

DJ Steven provided the music throughout the day.

Including an annual tradition; a karaoke performance of ' Take Me Home, Country Roads'

/g55A 2025 DESSERT CHAMPION

YUMMY! Thank you Gracelyn

Gracelyn made an Oreo Dirt Pudding creation complete with gummy worms

Gracelyn Haugh

FOOD, GLORIOUS FOOD!

Volunteer grill masters hard at work.

Pasta, macaroni, and potato salads from Clark's Sunrise Market in Honesdale.

Thank you to Matt Collins and MC's Kitchen and Outdoors for making pulled pork so popular, there wasn't time to take a proper photograph.

/g44A VOLUNTEER APPRECIATION

A big thank you to the Recreation committee, Maintenance, Security, and volunteers who gave their time and resources to ensure this iconic community event was a resounding success.

Thank you to all who attended. Thank you to all who attended. See you next year

CONASHAUGH BUSINESS

Dear Members, Please join us in welcoming our new administrator!

Greetings, Conashaugh Lakes Members.

My name is Jill O'Neill. I have been a member of Conashaugh Lakes since July 2003, during which time I raised five children. Conashaugh Lakes has been and continues to be a wonderful community in which to raise a family. My  children  grew  up  riding  their  bikes,  playing  basketball,  and  spending summers at the pool.

It  is  with  great  pleasure  that  I  accept  the  position  of  Administrator.  I  look forward  to  collaborating  with  the  Board  of  Directors,  office  staff,  and community  members.  I  began  my  career  in  community  management  in 2003 as the Administrative Assistant to the Property Manager at Pine Ridge Community Association in Bushkill, Pennsylvania. After six years with Pine Ridge, I was offered the Office Manager/Bookkeeper position at Wild Acres Lakes  Property  Owners'  Association  in  Dingmans  Ferry.  While  working  at Wild Acres, I earned my CMCA  (Certified Manager of Community Associations) and AMS (Association Management Specialist) Certifications. Within four years, I was promoted to Director of Operations, where I served the community for an additional five years.

Throughout my years in community management, I have attended numerous committee meetings for Budget and Finance, Bylaws, Rules and Regulations, Recreation, and Security. Additionally, I have collaborated with Maintenance  Departments  and  contractors  on  road  paving  projects,  highrisk dam projects, pool repairs, and more.

I take my role as Administrator very seriously. My goals are to maintain the financial stability of  Conashaugh  Lakes,  complete  projects  on time,  and  continue  providing  a  space  where families can enjoy raising their children.

Jill O'Neill

Boxes will be hung, with the picture below of Pop Tabs by the Mailboxes, Office, Recreation Building and Compactors. Drop off all your Pop Tabs and I will bring them to the Ronald McDonald House packaged with love from The Members of Conashaugh Lakes

This baseball season at PNC Field, home of the Scranton/Wilkes-Barre RailRiders, the Ronald McDonald House of Scranton is going BIG! They're on a mission to collect more Pop Tabs than ever before and set a world record-all while helping families stay close to their children's medical care.

Why Pop Tabs?

They are pure aluminum, easy to collect, and turn into funding for their House. Every tab helps provide housing, meals, and support to families in need. The more they collect, the closer they get to making history!

CONASHAUGH BUSINESS

We're excited to announce that the Conashaugh Lakes community pool is set to open on schedule this Memorial Day weekend! While earlier phone estimates had raised concerns about potentially costly repairs that might have delayed the season, recent inperson evaluations brought great news: those major fixes aren't necessary after all. Thanks to a closer look by professionals on-site, we've identified simpler, more efficient solutions that will get the pool up and running right on time-and just in time for the holiday.

These new developments not only mean summer fun can start without delay, but also ensure the pool will remain easy to maintain throughout the season. This gives the community more breathing room to thoughtfully plan for the pool's long-term future without sacrificing this year's enjoyment. We appreciate everyone's patience and support, and we can't wait to see you poolside for another great summer at Conashaugh Lakes!

Bird Seed Summer Ornaments

INSTRUCTIONS

Combine 2 packages of gelatin ,1/2 cup cold water and 1/2 cup boiling water.

Stir until the gelatin is completely dissolved.

Add the corn syrup and stir until combined.

Add the birdseed and mix well.

MATERIALS

2.5 cups Birdseed

2 Packages Unflavoured Gelatin, 2 Tablespoons total

2 Tablespoons Corn Syrup

1 Cup Water

12 Cookie Cutters

3 Drinking Straws , cut into 2″ long pieces Twine

Place the bowl in the refrigerator for about 10 minutes until the liquid firms up enough that it won't leak out from under the cookie cutters.

Set your cookie cutters onto a parchment lined baking sheet and fill them with spoonfuls of the birdseed mixture. Using the back of the spoon, press down the birdseed mixture firmly to fill in all the gaps. Fill the cookie cutters to the top.

Press the drinking straws into each of the shapes leaving at least 1/2″ of space between the hole and the edge of the shape.

Place the ornaments in the refrigerator overnight.

To remove the cookie cutters, gently pull the metal away from the edges on all side then gently push the birdseed ornaments out of the cookie cutters. Gently pull the straws out.

Thread a piece of twine through the hole and tie the ends in a knot.

Hang the birdseed ornaments from tree branches, leaving room nearby for the birds to perch on while eating.

HOMEMADE TUNA & YOGURT CAT TREATS

INGREDIENTS

1 can (5 oz/142g) tuna in water, drained

1/4 cup (60ml) plain unsweetened yogurt

1 tablespoon catnip (optional)

OPTIONAL ADD-INS:

1 teaspoon olive oil

1-2 tablespoons low-sodium chicken broth

INSTRUCTIONS

Drain tuna thoroughly in a colander.

Place tuna in mixing bowl and mash well with a fork until you achieve a smooth consistency.

Add yogurt and optional catnip, mixing until completely combined.

If using add-ins, incorporate them now until well blended.

Carefully spoon or pipe mixture into ice cube tray/mold cavities, filling each about 3/4 full.

Freeze for 2 hours or until completely firm.

FROZEN DOG TREATS

INGREDIENTS

2 cups chopped seedless watermelon

15 tablespoons ( just under 1 cup ) plain

yogurt

INSTRUCTIONS

Puree watermelon chunks until smooth.

Add 1 tablespoon of yogurt to each space in your mold or ice cube tray.

Fill the rest of the way with watermelon puree.

Freeze until solid, about 4 hours.

Remove treats from mold* and store in an air-tight container in the freezer.

Bins located in the mailbox area are for single stream recycling of household items only - it is not a collection box for miscellaneous metal items ( strollers, bbq's, treadmills, etc )

As a reminder, member vs member disputes /harassment matters are not handled by the office. Harassment is a crime and needs to be reported to the Pennsylvania State Police .

Matters involving domestic/child or animal abuse need to be r eported directly to agencies outside the community designated to handle such matters. The office cannot report these incidents for members. If you are a witness to any kind of these abuses, you must contact the agency directly.

When our security personnel are doing property checks , keep in mind they are doing them at the behest of the property owners. Telling them to get off the properties they are checking after they told you what they are doing is not the correct thing to do.

Tailgating continues to be an issue. It is apparent that most people do not realize it is against the rules and regulations. They can download the Rules and Regs from our website here. We may need to address this issue another way so all members are aware.

TABLE

HOME SECURITY

Here is a list of suggestions of what we can do to keep our family, home and property safe.

1. Secure Doors and Windows

Use solid core or metal doors for all entry points.

Install deadbolt locks on exterior doors.

Reinforce sliding glass doors with a security bar or pin.

Ensure all windows have secure locks and consider window bars or security film.

2. Install a Security System

Invest in a home security system with alarms, cameras, and motion detectors.

Display security system signage to deter potential intruders.

3. Use Outdoor Lighting

Install motion-activated lights around entry points and dark areas of your property.

Keep outdoor lights on during the night to increase visibility.

4. Create the Illusion of Occupancy

Use timers to turn on lights, radios, or TVs when you're not home.

Have a trusted neighbor collect your mail and packages while you're away.

5. Maintain Your Yard

Keep bushes and trees trimmed to eliminate hiding spots for intruders.

Use gravel or pebbles as ground cover near windows and doors to make noise when walked on.

6. Secure Your Garage

Keep garage doors closed and locked.

Install a security camera or motion sensor light in the garage.

7. Use Smart Technology

Consider  smart  locks  and  doorbell cameras to monitor entry points.

Use  smart  home  systems  that  allow you to control lights and alarms remotely.

8. Be Cautious with Social Media

Avoid posting about your travel plans or being away from home on social media.

Wait until you're back home to share vacation photos.

9. Install a Peephole or Video Doorbell

Use a peephole or video doorbell to see who is at your door before opening it.

HOME SECURITY

10. Keep Valuables Out of Sight

Store valuables, including electronics, jewelry, and important documents, in a safe or in hidden locations.

Avoid leaving expensive items in plain view, especially near windows.

11. Know Your Neighbors

Look out for each other's homes and report any suspicious activity

12. Reinforce Windows

Consider installing window locks or security screens.

Use shatter-resistant glass or window film to make it harder to break in.

By implementing these safety tips, you can significantly reduce the risk of a break-in and help protect your home and belongings.

Dear Members, Please join us in welcoming our new administrator!

My name is Jill O'Neill. I have been a member of Conashaugh Lakes since July 2003, during which time I raised five children. Conashaugh Lakes has been and continues to be a wonderful community in which to raise a family. My  children  grew  up  riding  their  bikes,  playing  basketball,  and  spending summers at the pool.

It  is  with  great  pleasure  that  I  accept  the  position  of  Administrator.  I  look forward  to  collaborating  with  the  Board  of  Directors,  office  staff,  and community  members.  I  began  my  career  in  community  management  in 2003 as the Administrative Assistant to the Property Manager at Pine Ridge Community Association in Bushkill, Pennsylvania. After six years with Pine Ridge, I was offered the Office Manager/Bookkeeper position at Wild Acres Lakes  Property  Owners'  Association  in  Dingmans  Ferry.  While  working  at Wild Acres, I earned my CMCA  (Certified Manager of Community Associations) and AMS (Association Management Specialist) Certifications. Within four years, I was promoted to Director of Operations, where I served the community for an additional five years.

Throughout my years in community management, I have attended numerous committee meetings for Budget and Finance, Bylaws, Rules and Regulations, Recreation, and Security. Additionally, I have collaborated with Maintenance  Departments  and  contractors  on  road  paving  projects,  highrisk dam projects, pool repairs, and more.

I take my role as Administrator very seriously. My goals are to maintain the financial stability of  Conashaugh  Lakes,  complete  projects  on time,  and  continue  providing  a  space  where families can enjoy raising their children.

We're excited to announce that the Conashaugh Lakes community pool is set to open on schedule this Memorial Day weekend! While earlier phone estimates had raised concerns about potentially costly repairs that might have delayed the season, recent inperson evaluations brought great news: those major fixes aren't necessary after all. Thanks to a closer look by professionals on-site, we've identified simpler, more efficient solutions that will get the pool up and running right on time-and just in time for the holiday.

These new developments not only mean summer fun can start without delay, but also ensure the pool will remain easy to maintain throughout the season. This gives the community more breathing room to thoughtfully plan for the pool's long-term future without sacrificing this year's enjoyment. We appreciate everyone's patience and support, and we can't wait to see you poolside for another great summer at Conashaugh Lakes!

With summer on the horizon, for many families it's swimsuit shopping season. This year, make a choice that's not only stylish, but also helps swimmers be safer by choosing bold, visible colors that don't camouflage easily in a pool.

Above are 14 different swimsuit colors in a pool, showing how they appear in three feet of water, with a still and agitated surface. While many dark colors were visible against the blue-bottomed pool, they would be easier to dismiss as shadow or debris, especially when their profile is broken up by surface agitation, and their apparent size possibly altered by refraction. The most visible? 'Neon orange, neon green, bright yellow and hot pink.' 'Think 1980's colors.'

Combine 2 packages of gelatin ,1/2 cup cold water and 1/2 cup boiling water.
Stir until the gelatin is completely dissolved.
Add the corn syrup and stir until combined.
Add the birdseed and mix well.
3 Drinking Straws , cut into 2″ long pieces Twine
Place the bowl in the refrigerator for about 10 minutes until the liquid firms up enough that it won't leak out from under the cookie cutters.

Set your cookie cutters onto a parchment lined baking sheet and fill them with spoonfuls of the birdseed mixture. Using the back of the spoon, press down the birdseed mixture firmly to fill in all the gaps. Fill the cookie cutters to the top.
Press the drinking straws into each of the shapes leaving at least 1/2″ of space between the hole and the edge of the shape.
Place the ornaments in the refrigerator overnight.
To remove the cookie cutters, gently pull the metal away from the edges on all side then gently push the birdseed ornaments out of the cookie cutters. Gently pull the straws out.
Thread a piece of twine through the hole and tie the ends in a knot.
Hang the birdseed ornaments from tree branches, leaving room nearby for the birds to perch on while eating.
1 can (5 oz/142g) tuna in water, drained
Drain tuna thoroughly in a colander.
Place tuna in mixing bowl and mash well with a fork until you achieve a smooth consistency.
Add yogurt and optional catnip, mixing until completely combined.
If using add-ins, incorporate them now until well blended.
Carefully spoon or pipe mixture into ice cube tray/mold cavities, filling each about 3/4 full.
Freeze for 2 hours or until completely firm.
Add 1 tablespoon of yogurt to each space in your mold or ice cube tray.
Fill the rest of the way with watermelon puree.
Remove treats from mold* and store in an air-tight container in the freezer.

What You Need to Know about Sun Safety

Spending Ɵme outside is a great way to be physically acƟve and reduce stress. You can work and play outside without raising your skin cancer risk by protecƟng your skin from the sun.

ProtecƟon from UV rays is important all year, not just during the summer. UV rays can reach you on cloudy and cool days, and they reŇect oī of surfaces like water, cement, sand, and snow.

Most skin cancers are caused by too much exposure to ultraviolet (UV) light. UV rays are an invisible kind of radiaƟon that comes from the sun, tanning beds, and sunlamps. UV rays can damage skin cells.

How to protect your skin from the sun

You can reduce your risk of sun damage and skin cancer by staying in the shade under an umbrella, tree, or other shelter. Your best bet to protect your skin is to use sunscreen or wear protecƟve clothing when you're outside-even when you're in the shade.

Shade

Clothing

Hat

When possible, wear long -sleeved shirts and long pants and skirts, which can provide protecƟon from UV rays. If wearing this type of clothing isn't pracƟcal, try to wear a T -shirt or a beach cover -up. Clothes made from Ɵghtly woven fabric oīer the best protecƟon. A wet T -shirt oīers much less UV protecƟon than a dry one, and darker colors may oīer more protecƟon than lighter colors. Some clothing is cerƟĮed under internaƟonal standards as oīering UV protecƟon.

For the most protecƟon, wear a hat that has a brim all the way around that shades your face, your ears, and

Sunglasses

the back of your neck. A Ɵghtly woven fabric, such as canvas, works best to protect your skin from UV rays. Avoid straw hats with holes that let sunlight through. A darker hat may oīer more UV protecƟon. If you wear a baseball cap, you should also protect your ears and the back of your neck by wearing clothing that covers those areas, using sunscreen, or staying in the shade.

Sunglasses protect your eyes from UV rays and reduce the risk of cataracts. They also protect the tender skin around your eyes from sun exposure.

Sunscreen

Sunglasses that block both UVA and UVB rays oīer the best protecƟon. Most sunglasses sold in the United States, regardless of cost, meet this standard. Wrap -around sunglasses work best because they block UV rays from sneaking in from the side.

Put on broad spectrum sunscreen that Įlters out both UVA and UVB rays and has an SPF of 15 or higher before you go outside. Don't forget to put a thick layer on all exposed skin. Get help for hard -to -reach places like your back. And remember, sunscreen works best when combined with other opƟons.

Sunscreen is not recommended for babies who are 6 months old or younger. The US Food and Drug AdministraƟon recommends keeping infants out of the sun during midday and using protecƟve clothing if they have to be in the sun.

SPF. Sunscreens are assigned a sun protecƟon factor (SPF), which is a number that rates how well they Įlter out UV rays. Higher numbers indicate more protecƟon. You should use a broad spectrum sunscreen with SPF of 15 or higher.

ReapplicaƟon. Sunscreen wears oī. Put it on again if you stay out in the sun for more than 2 hours and aŌer swimming, sweaƟng, or toweling oī.

The Rules on Fireworks Safety

You know the damage fireworks can do to humans: severe burns and mangled fingers. The fact is the environment is also at risk from pyrotechnics. A firecracker flung by a 15 -year -old boy during a burn ban started a 2017 fire in Oregon ' s Columbia River Gorge that burned for three months and charred 50,000 acres. Pockets of fire were still smoldering nine months after the blaze began.

The lesson here is clear enough. You need to observe extreme care in celebrating the 4th with fireworks. Know all the dangers before you light the first fuse.

The safety Ɵps from Homeland Security come from its TransportaƟon Safety Laboratory (TSL).

❖ Never place a part of your body directly over a Įrework or hold a Įrework in your hand when lighƟng.

❖ Always use Įreworks outdoors and keep a bucket of water or a hose nearby in case of accidents.

❖ Light only one Įrework at a Ɵme.

❖ For ground -based devices such as fountains, the perimeter should be 35 feet out.

❖ Designate a safe perimeter to keep people safely away from Įreworks.

❖ For aerial devices, it should be 150 feet. Fireworks that don't go oī when you light them can sƟll explode.

❖ Let duds sit for Įve or 10 minutes before you pick them up to dowse them in water.

Include pet safety as well as human safety in your plans. Pets find fireworks highly stressful. Bring your pets indoors, close curtains and blinds and turn on the radio to provide some distraction. Leave treats filled with food to comfort animals.

Keep the weather in mind when using fireworks. Never use fireworks if your locale has a burn ban. Never set off fireworks where falling embers could ignite buildings or vegetation.

Homeland Security suggests using alternatives to fireworks such as party poppers, bubbles, silly string, or glow sticks.

Sparklers may appear to be a safe alternative to things that go boom, but they are not. The NSC says sparklers burn at 2,000 degrees enough to melt metal. For children under five, sparklers account for half of all fireworks injuries. Keep them away from kids and use glow sticks, confetti poppers or colored streamers.

Final word on fireworks comes from the National Safety Council, which offers this as the safest way to enjoy fireworks: ' Grab a blanket and a patch of lawn. Kick back and let the experts handle the fireworks show. '

Japanese Barberry

Berberis thunbergii DC. Barberry family (Berberidaceae)

Origin: Japan

Background

1875. Seeds were sent from Russia to the Arnold Arboretum in Boston, Massachusetts. In 1896, it was planted at the New York Botanic Garden. It was eventually promoted as a substitute for Berberis vulgaris, an exotic plant introduced and used by early settlers from Europe for hedgerows, dyes and jams, and later found to be a host for the black stem rust of wheat.

Japanese barberry was introduced to the United States as an ornamental in

Distribution and Habitat

Japanese barberry occurs and is reported to be invasive throughout the northeastern U.S. from Maine to North Carolina and west to Wisconsin and Missouri. It grows well in full sun to deep shade and forms dense stands in closed canopy forests, open woodlands, wetlands, fields and other areas.

Ecological Threat

Where it is well established, barberry displaces many native herbaceous and woody plants. In large infestations, its leaf litter causes changes in the chemistry of the soil, making it more basic.

Description and Biology

Plant: spiny deciduous shrub typically to 3, but someƟmes to 6 Ō. in height; branches are deeply grooved, brown and usually have simple spines as opposed to 3 -pronged spines in exoƟc invasive European barberry ( B. vulgaris ) and the naƟve Allegheny barberry ( B. canadensis ).

Flowers, fruits and seeds: Ňowering occurs in spring; abundant pale yellow Ňowers occur along the enƟre length of the stem in clusters of two to four; fruits are bright red berries about 1/3 in. long that mature July to October and persist through the winter.

Leaves: small ½ -1½ inches long and shaped like small spatulas or narrow ovals, with a color ranging from green to bluish -green to dark reddish purple.

Spreads: seed produced in abundance and eaten by birds like turkey and grouse and other wildlife that spread it far and wide; local vegetaƟve spread is through root creepers and Ɵp rooƟng branches.

Prevention and Control

Do not plant Japanese or European barberry. No biological control is available for this plant. Wearing thick gloves to protect from spines, young plants can be pulled up by hand. A Weed Wrench® can be used to uproot older shrubs when soil is moist. Shrubs can also be mowed or cut repeatedly. Treatment with systemic herbicides like glyphosate and triclopyr has been very effective

Are You a Thermometer or a Thermostat?

In the realm of personal growth and self -awareness, a metaphor often used is comparing people to thermometers and thermostats. But what does this mean and which one are you?

The Thermometer:

who are like thermometers tend to mirror the emotions, attitudes and behaviors of those around them. If their environment is positive, they're uplifted.  Conversely,  if they're surrounded by negativity, their mood and actions shift to reƪect that negativity.

A thermometer is a passive instrument. It reƪects the temperature of its surroundings but has no control over it. Similarly, people

Characteristics of a Thermometer Person:

-Adaptive: They easily blend into their environment.

-Reactive: They respond to the energy around them.

-Inƪuenced: Their mood and productivity are swayed by external factors.

The Thermostat:

Characteristics of a Thermostat Person:

A thermostat, on the other hand, is an active instrument. It not only measures the temperature but also adjusts it to a desired setting. People who resemble thermostats have the power to inƪuence their surroundings. They set the tone and create an atmosphere based on their internal mindset and values, rather than being swayed by external circumstances.

-Proactive: They take charge of their environment.

-Resilient: Their mood and productivity are determined by their internal state rather than external factors (very important characteristic)

-Inƪuential: They have the ability to inspire and uplift others.

Which One Are You?

Reƪecting on this metaphor, ask yourself: do you tend to react to the environment around you, or do you take control and shape it? Neither is inherently right or wrong, but understanding where you stand can help you grow.

Tips for Becoming More Like a Thermostat:

Cultivate Self -Awareness: Regularly check in with your thoughts and feelings. Understand what triggers your reactions and why.

Set Clear Intentions: Decide the kind of energy and atmosphere you want to create, both for yourself and those around you.

Practice Emotional Regulation: Develop strategies to manage your emotions, so they don't control you.

Surround Yourself with Positivity: While you should aim to inƪuence your environment, it's also wise to choose supportive and positive surroundings whenever possible.

Lead by Example: Demonstrate the behavior, attitude and values you wish to see in others.

In conclusion, whether you're a thermometer or a thermostat, the key is awareness and intentionality. By understanding your tendencies, you can strive to be the person who not only measures the climate but also creates it.

Which one do you resonate with more, the thermometer or the thermostat?

Understanding Cyberbullying: A Simple Guide for Children and Adults

Cyberbullying is a signiĮcant issue that aīects both children and adults. It involves using technology, such as social media, text messages, or emails, to harm, threaten, or harass others. Here ' s a brief overview of what cyberbullying is, its eīects, and how to address it.

What is Cyberbullying?

-Harassment: Sending hurƞul messages repeatedly.

Cyberbullying can take many forms, including:

-ImpersonaƟon: Pretending to be someone else online to spread false informaƟon.

-Doxxing: Sharing personal informaƟon without consent to harm someone.

-Exclusion: IntenƟonally leaving someone out of online groups or conversaƟons.

Eīects of Cyberbullying

VicƟms may experience:

Cyberbullying can have serious consequences for both vicƟms and bullies.

-Low self -esteem

-Diĸculty concentraƟng

-Anxiety and depression

-Changes in sleep paƩerns

Perpetrators may also face negaƟve outcomes, such as disciplinary acƟons and strained relaƟonships.

How to Address Cyberbullying

-Talk to Someone: Encourage children to share their experiences with a trusted adult or friend.

For Children:

-Don ' t Respond: Advise them not to retaliate or engage with the bully.

For Adults:

-Document Everything: Keep records of messages or posts that demonstrate bullying behavior.

-Recognize the Signs: Be aware of changes in behavior, such as withdrawal from social interacƟons.

-Report the Behavior: Use available reporƟng tools on social media plaƞorms and consider legal acƟon if necessary.

-Encourage CommunicaƟon: Create an open environment where individuals feel safe discussing their online experiences.

Conclusion

Cyberbullying is a pervasive issue that can have lasƟng eīects on individuals of all ages. By recognizing the signs and taking proacƟve steps, both children and adults can work together to combat cyberbullying and create a safer online environment. Remember, everyone deserves to feel safe and respected, both online and oŋine.

RATTLESNAKES

Yes, rattlesnakes are found in Pennsylvania. The two venomous species native to the state are the Timber Rattlesnake and the Eastern Massasauga. The Eastern Copperhead is also venomous but not a rattlesnake. Timber Rattlesnakes are more common and found in 51 of Pennsylvania's 67 counties, according to the Pennsylvania Fish and Boat Commission.

Rattlesnake Species in Pennsylvania: Timber Rattlesnake (Crotalus horridus):

Eastern Massasauga (Sistrurus catenatus catenatus):

This is the most commonly encountered rattlesnake in Pennsylvania. They are known for their stout bodies and variable color patterns, which can be brown or black bands on a yellow to black background, according to the Pennsylvania Natural Heritage Program.

This species prefers wet meadows and prairie areas, which are found in speciƤc western counties of Pennsylvania.

Safety Measures

If you encounter a raƩlesnake, remain calm, avoid sudden movements, and maintain a safe distance (at least 10 feet). Do not aƩempt to kill or handle the snake, and do not throw objects at it. Alert others to the snake's presence and keep children and pets away. If biƩen, seek immediate medical aƩenƟon.

Safety Tips

Panicking can lead to sudden movements that may startle or provoke the snake.

Stay Calm:

Maintain Distance:

Don't Provoke:

Rattlesnakes typically strike when they feel threatened, so keeping a safe distance (at least 10 feet) is crucial.

Avoid throwing objects, attempting to move the snake, or otherwise disturbing it.

Let other people in the area know about the snake's location and advise them to proceed with caution. Keep Pets and Children Away:

Alert Others:

Ensure children and pets are kept at a safe distance from the snake.

If bitten, seek immediate medical attention.

Seek Medical Attention:

If you hear a rattle:

safely back away, do so. On Trails:

Stop and locate the sound before reacting. If you can

Stay on designated trails, avoid tall grass, and be aware of your surroundings. Keep your dog on a leash.

If the snake doesn't move oơ the trail, it's often best to wait it out or turn back.

If it doesn't move:
